description:
I've been wanting to come here for so long after seeing the swing pics all over Instagram and I finally had the chance! The view was amazing and the swing was super fun! The hike was really just a short climb up a small hill. There was a very short line when we got there, and people were very kind about taking pictures for us. At one point, these little girls would not get off the swings but I could see why they wouldn't want to get off haha. It's such a fun spot if you love viewpoints and are able to find some fun in the simplest things like a good ole' swing. Super recommended if you're ever in SF!! 

ps. If you happen to have a hard time finding this spot like we did, it's just at the top of the hill facing the bay side, not land. And make sure to bring a jacket! It's windy up there!
author: Cherin K.

description:
Exceptional views of the city with plenty of street parking abound. It was great to not have to travel too far and still feel a little escape from urban life. It is extremely dog-friendly and I suppose dogs are allowed unleashed here because the majority of them were not on leashes. This would be great for a little urban/nature jog or light hike. Slight incline but pretty easy terrain.

Walking around really did remind me of the truth that there are more dogs than human children in San Francisco. I counted 3 infants/toddlers on my stroll and I lost track of the number of dogs I saw.
author: Jess Y.

description:
My bf and I were here for a spontaneous outdoor painting date and found that they had a swing on a tree.  

There was a short line for the swing, but the people were very nice to wait and to take photos for each other!  I would prefer to come here than the Billy Goat's if you are looking for a swing in the City.  

Con: Very windy!! Bring your jacket or cap with you.
author: Shuyi L.

description:
5 stars for the view, 3 stars for the hike.

Besides Twin Peaks Bernal Heights has the best 360 view of the city.  It's even better in the sense that you are much closer to the fresh air of the Bay and you don't get a million tourists because most of them have never heard of Bernal Heights.

The views are spectacular on a clear day and a lot of people just hang out and picnic looking out over the views of the city, bay, and beyond.  Many people come here with their dog.

For hiking there are a few different trails that go up and around the hill but there isn't a definite path so there are a few different options to explore. The incline isn't too strenuous so if you are doing this as a hike and want a better/longer workout I'd suggest incorporating  some of the numerous staircases located in Bernal Heights.  The Esmeralda stairs located on the Western side of the hill is probably the most popular one.  It has a path directly to the trails as well as an amazing long slide.
author: Joan W.

description:
This place has incredible views. Even the parking's nearby area is a great photography spot.

The hike is easy uphill. I took a shortcut downhill (walking on the hilly dirt path instead of the flat main path), but find the dirt very dry & slippery.  There were many rocks that would roll once stepped on. I was wearing decent walking shoes but not particularly with strong gripping soles. I personally think the shortcut paths can be better laid out/ maintained so it's safer and easier to walk on, especially for kids.

When I visited on a weekday evening, this place had more dogs than humans. Not a bad thing, but gets a bit uncomfortable if you are slightly allergic! Some dogs are unleashed, which made it a bit challenging to stay completely dog-touch-free (?) throughout the walk. 

Also couldn't find the swing!! Not sure if it's still up (?)
author: Jess W.

description:
San Francisco's best kept secret! 

This place is not super crowded, there's parking, the hike is short and easy (like, 10 minutes and I did it in a dress and ballet flats) and the view is AMAZE. 

There's a swing on top for all your Insta photos but there's also lots of other lookouts and a grassy area to sit and enjoy the view. 

Its a bit further out in the city so there's not a lot of tourists. We came on a Saturday afternoon and it was shockingly not too crowded and oh-so-romantic.
author: Ninette C.

description:
Very Thankful my Son has been enjoying this beautiful and gorgeous scenic destination and wanted to share the experience with me! There was easy parking at the top of the hill and the walk up is very easy. There were numerous friendly dogs and happy folks enjoying a beautiful day in the city. 
The views are AMAZING full circle and the best part for myself is the SWING! Whhheeeeeeeeee!!!!!! I had So Much Fun sitting on the swing and enjoying the freedom that comes with your feet hanging off from the ground, wind blowing in your hair and enjoying the beautiful view all around me! I will  surely return again just to enjoy the swing and views of the city!
author: Yoh M.

description: We got here around 930 ish on a Saturday morning and this was a pleasant hike.  Loved it even more w the dogs hiking w us! There is definitely a paved road for the uphill walk but there is also a tougher unpaved way  up the hill.   On the top of the hike was a pleasant swing that overseas the city! Beautiful place for a beautiful morning
author: Joyce W.

description: Took my dog out for a walk, found this place near our home and enjoyed every step of our hike. The view is just as amazing like the twin peaks. A small hike but so worth it. Theirs benches to sit and enjoy a quick snack and enjoy the view. Great location for a date :) theirs also a swing, which is why Lots of locals and tourist come lol ... it's a cool spot, don't be lazy. Get your ass out here and enjoy the breeze and view :)
author: Melissa H.

description:
Lovely park to oversee the city residential view!  

Great for dog walk and just to simply be here! 

Swing on the top of the hill to feel the free flow breeze.  Joy.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
On my first ever trip to SF, my friend recommended going to Bernal Heights to have a beautiful view of the city.

The park is very dog friendly and it's almost like we were in doggy heaven. Dogs of all shapes, sizes, and ages just enjoying the park with their owners or dog walkers! It was awesome!

Once we made our way to the top, we found the tree with the rope tree swing and tire swing. The flat rope swing was the one we saw in a lot of the IG photos posted about Bernal Heights, so of course we had our turns swinging on the swing and getting a IG worthy picture to post.

Getting to the top of the hill was relatively easy, the slightly paved path goes around the hill but we took a shortcut up the steeper path and got to the swing within 15 minutes.
author: Cara Y.

description:
A dog park on top of the hill with a nice view of San Francisco.  People go hiking up the hill with their dogs.  I've seen people take pictures here, have a picnic, wedding, kids playing, and dogs running around.  There is also one regular swing and one tire swing hung on a tree on top of the hill.  Not much grass, mostly dirt.  The hill is rocky and slightly steep. If you like to hike, Bernel Park is a 1-mile loop trail. 

::Experience::
A stunning 360 view of SF!  It's a short walk on top and around the hill.  There are different ways you can go up to the hill.  We entered at the dead end.  It's a simple place with a great view.  The best part is meeting all the friendly dogs and owners.   We also flew a kite too.  

::Tip::
Bring a jacket 

::M's Notes::
-No restrooms
-Small parking lot at the bottom
-Park at the side of the hill
-Water fountain
author: MarVy S.

description:
lookin' for an IG worthy spot?  well, this is it!  super short "hike" to the top.  once you get to the top, you get an amazing 360 view of the city!  they also have a swing under a tree which is also great for pics.  

you can also bring your lunch here and have a picnic too.  its perfect to just sit there hangout and soak in all that beauty.  

+++you get to see so many cute doggies!!
author: mong linh n.

description:
Was looking for a place to take my dog and came across this. It's dog friendly, has a tire swing and a tree swing at the top, and has a 270 degree breathtaking view of the city. The view alone sold it for me. You don't realize how high you're going up until you start seeing the top of roofs. It's a short hike that anyone  and any dog can easily do. There is a short cut too, but just be careful since it's steeper and there are rocks that can make you slip, but very doable! I took the short cut with my dog and got to the top within 20? 30? minutes. I was just taken away by the view. I kept taking photos after photos haha. 

Once you get to the top you will find a tree swing and a tire swing that a lot of people come there to take photos of. 

You can continue hiking down to the other side to get down from the hill. Parking is limited on one side, but if you go through to the other side there is more parking in the residential area. Overall, spent about an hour to an hour and half going up and down and taking lots of photos. Highly recommend it to anyone in the area or looking for a nice park.
author: Stephy L.

description: The tree swing was gone when I went 3/2018. Still beautiful views and a nice easy, quiet, quick relaxing hike.
author: Kerith H.

description: Probably the easiest "hike" in San Francisco. From the bottom of the hill, it maybe takes about 10-15 minutes to get to the top. Once you're at the top, it's flatter so you see people picnicking, dogs running around, etc. Great 360 views of the city up here. Definitely underrated, but is nice because it's never crowded.
author: Lillian B.

description: Amazing views. Bring a jacket to combat the somewhat torrential winds this summer. Bring your pooches too! Walk around the hill, on the hill and on top of it as well!
author: Michael Vincent R.

description: Beautiful view and nice "hike" to the top. Lots of puppies roaming around. If you are coming for the swing, like I was, you will be sad to hear that the swing is GONE
author: Melody S.

description:
My sister is pretty great at finding the best spots to visit in San Francisco. We primarily came to this park to visit the swing at the top of the hill, but it's also a popular hiking spot for locals as well as a dog park. There's apparently a teal colored rock somewhere and a labyrinth formed by stones at the bottom of the hill (in some odd design it seemed like). We parked on Bernal Heights and ended up making a big loop and climbing over several hills before we reached the swing. There's an easier way to get to the top if you start by the labyrinth I think. 

But anyway you hike, you're going to get a good view when you reach the top. If it's not too hot or too cold and you're there on a good day, you'll oversee SF.

We got to the top of the mountain where the swing was. Apparently somebody had just replaced the swing during Christmas and secured some new rope onto the tree, so it was much safer than the prior swing that was there. If you're afraid of heights, it's definitely a little scary pushing off of the ground and swinging into the air. The swing goes out pretty far! My sister and I came primarily to take pictures, but there were several kids who were captivated by the swing and sat there swinging for quite awhile. 

With the green grassy hills, clear cut roads and the blue sky as the backdrop of San Francisco, you'll definitely want to check out Bernal Heights if you're in the area!
author: Tiffany C.

description: You figure any place with the name "heights" in it will be a great place to get awesome views. Naturally you won't be disappointed here if you came for beautiful vistas of the city. You can start your way around the hill and work yourself up via trails or at certain sections cross over to get an easier streamlined shortcut to the top. Some paths are pretty narrow and treacherous looking but the locals made it look so easy walking them.
author: Wally B.

description: This park was recommended by a friend and I'm glad we went. It's an easy walk walk up. We just drove up the hill and parked our car and started walking. Once you get to the top of the hill there's two swings. If you sit on the swings be careful because the wooden swing is slippery and once you push off its a scary thrill and rush of excitement because you're swinging as if you're going over the city. It has a great view of the city that you can't complain about. It's definitely a relaxing place to go and clear your mind. On our way down we saw over 100 dogs off leashes taking their walks which was a total plus.
author: Sandy L.

description:
This park is extremely convenient and offers great views of the city. From here you can see the golden gate bridge poking out from the woods and the residential areas if the city. You can also see the famous twin peaks, and you should head over to them as they offer much better views.

The park itself feels more of a neighborhood park and attracts a lot of locals with dogs. Beware, most of them are off leash. The appearance of the park is more of red rock/soil mounds than of woods, especially at the top. It has limited seating areas with very little dedicated vehicular/bike parking.
author: Emmanuel T.

description: If you want an easy and short hike with a beautiful view, this is the spot. You'll see people with dogs. 5-10 minute hike to the top.
author: Alliver V.

description:
This is a great park to walk with dogs, solo, friends or groups, the amazing SF Bay view will be all under your toes once you hike to near the top, hike around hill's peaceful summit ( A paved limited-access road and a well-defined dirt trails provided access to the summit) enjoy breathtaking clear view of San Francisco Bay, Golden Gate Bridge, San Bruno Mountain ...a rope swing that if you dared sitting on, you can feel the very free flying feelings. parks open from 5am-Midnight, address: Bernal Heights Blvd., SF, today, Bernal Hilltop restoration projects, programs are working together to preserve and restore Bernal Hill's natural history. 
We enjoy very much of this beauty natural park, hope you too.
author: Anne C.

description:
another hidden gem in the city! the view here is super awesome in the morning. I got here at around 7am and there are already a bunch of people walking their dogs , running and walking. 
Dog friendly! my dogs and i really enjoyed this morning hike. will definitely come back again
author: Tina H.

description:
- A lovely neighborhood with loads of stairs to climb.  
- This park is filled with hikers, families and dogs. 
- Can get windy up there, so dress in layers. 
- A great place for a stroll & to enjoy the views. ( See Golden Gate Bridge, twin peaks, the distant downtown)
- I went there on a Sunday and parking was a breeze, perfect for Sunday walks.
This was one of my favorite walks, so go check it out and enjoy the outside!!!!
author: Elaine Y.

description:
A much recommended park to visit. 

 I came here on a beautiful Sunday morning. In my opinion, it's 10 times better than twin peaks. You don't have tourists swarming the ant hill and the drive isn't as windy or dangerous. Most of the people came to walk their dogs off leash and some fitheads came running up the hill like they were training to be marathon runners. 

My sister and I got dropped off at the entrance at the top and we proceeded to walk to the top of the hill. You get a beautiful 360 view of San Francisco and the surrounding areas like Daly City etc. There is a swing, but I am unwilling to hover and wait for someone else to get off the swing. Some girl was swinging for a full 30 minutes and a line started to form. 

If you want more of a strenuous walk, you should start at the foot of the hill and walk up. It goes up in circles, as it is a hill. For a more nice, relaxing walk, I just recommend getting dropped off at the top and even then, you'll still have to walk up a steep part. I would go every day if I lived nearby and I recommend this place for those who love scenic views.
author: Emily F.

description:
5 stars for the tree swing and tire swing photo op, but other than that, the park is kind of boring. There's a small parking lot at the entrance of Bernal Heights Park. You just follow the path all the way to the top and you'll see the crowd congregated around the tire swing and the tree swing. If you're feeling adventurous, there's a beaten path up the left side of the mountain right at the start of the paved hiking trail. If you want to scale the mountain, it'll lead you to the tree swing a lot faster.

You'll have to wait in line to take your photo on either swing. With the SF City views in the background, it's totally worth it. Gorgeous 360 degree view. Free parking and no entrance fee.
author: Denise H.

description: Nice easy walk. Great view. A little get away that most tourist miss . Thanks to the trees not too windy and the sun beams down on you pretty well. Also dog friendly so that's nice
author: Justin I.

description: Super easy to get to and super easy to walk up. I only went up the paved road so I can't speak for the actual hiking part. I went at 6pm and waited until 645pm to wait for the sunset. Unfortunately, the clouds were coming in so there wasn't much of a shot of a sunset. Either way, it was nice to just sit along the railings, pop in your earphones, and just relax with a nice view.
author: Martin N.

description:
THE POOP EMOJI ROCK IS GONE!! 

I came specifically to see the poop emoji rock, but it's now painted teal... Someone wrote "I miss the poop emoji" on the rock. Well, I do too! :(

But I did walk up to the top and the view is great. You can see all of SF as you walk around the gated area on top. 

Also, there is a swing at the top!

Anyone can hike this. Difficulty level is 0!
author: Darlene T.

description:
Bernal Heights Park is basically a large hill in the middle of the city and is a dog leash free zone for dogs to run freely in the hills and meet other friendly pups in the neighbourhood. 

Walking up the steep hill to get to Bernal Heights Park is an excellent way to work your gluts and your calf muscles. The main attraction of the park is the magnificent view at the top of the hill where you can see a magnificent view of San Francisco! Another beautiful part about the park is the swing hanging from a tree branch where people can sit on and swing on as if they were swinging over San Francisco! 

There's also mini hills that you can climb on to see a different view of San Francisco. These mini hills can get you down the park as well back into the residential areas so you don't have to climb up and down the same spot. I recommend staying on the path if it's rainy!
author: Kristy N.

description: Easiest route up to the swing is parking on Anderson & Bernal Heights & its about 0.1 mile walk up the roundabout hill, best view overlooking the city, easier to get to compared to Ina Coolbrith park
author: Precious C.

description:
What an amazing view of the city and surrounding neighborhoods. In all the years that I've come to visit San Francisco, I have yet to visit this look out point. On a clear day, you can see as far as the Bay bridge and Golden Gate Bridges. You can see the skyline of downtown and parts of the East Bay.

There's an access road to the top (there's a swing up there) and a dirt trail that wraps around the other side of the hill. Take both for a view from all sides of the park. Dogs off leash everywhere! And an adjacent hill with trails and blooming yellow flowers.
author: Sarah L.

description:
Gorgeous 360 view of San Francisco. You can see the Golden Gate Bridge, Bay Bridge, downtown, Sutro Tower, etc.! This is a must-visit and I'll be visiting with my mom quite frequently!

We parked at the entrance where there was a sign stating "Bernal Heights Hill". There is a small lot there, but you can also park on the side of the road before and after the lot. Just make sure you park on dirt and not on the actual road itself! I liked that they had several trails. My mom and I took the easy, paved route since my mom is 60. However, I saw steeper, unpaved routes for those who are more daring! They also have numerous benches on the way up to take a quick break or just to sit and enjoy the gorgeous view. If you like dogs, you'll love this place! It's considered a dog park of sorts I've heard. There is a labyrinth on your way up, though smaller and made of gravel, compared to the one at Lands End. Still a nice photo op! 

I'd say it took us about 30 minutes going up, and 20 minutes coming down. We were strolling at a very leisurely pace and took breaks to enjoy the breathtaking view. A hidden gem and a must-visit if you're ever in the city!
author: Kristi T.

description:
This place holds a special place in my heart as I keep the memory of dancing under the moonlight by the city of glimmering lights.

Definitely check out Bernal Heights Park early in the morning or in the evening. It's a very short hike to the top to enjoy the panoramic view of San Francisco. Just a teeny warning: as you try to find parking at night, you'd run into many couples making out in their cars. Awkward.
author: Solongo B.

description:
I am not sure why it took me so long to finally visit this park with my dogs. Truly it is a people and dog friendly place, where both can enjoy a stroll any time of the day. With 360 degree views of San Francisco, you'll want to mark this place as a spot to bring your out-of-town guests! I can only imagine what the views look like at night, with The City a-glow. 

The hike, which I would't really call a full on hike, is perhaps a 20-30 minute walk to the top. That is depending on your speed and whether your dog races to the top of course. The area is lush with Wildflowers, tall grass and California's State flower, the Poppy. 

Parking was extremely easy. I practically pulled into a spot at the park entrance at peak 12:30pm on a Sunday. Put on your walking shoes and go check it out!
author: Jaylena P.

description: Beautiful! I agree with those who said this park has some of the BEST views in the City! We came with friends and 5 kids total and explored, which was a bit stressful because it's steep and the rocks are sharp. The weather was warm and we enjoyed it overall. I wish the swing had been there!
author: L. W.
Wendy F.

description:
Today would not be complete, without a stroll around the Bernal Parks Hill......

With a coffee cup in hand, it's just Sunday morning tradition to take this amazing walk. You can see for miles & miles, the only thing to make it a complete walk, would have been Lucy.   

Next time.....
author: Janet T.

description: This place is probably my favorite view spot of the city. I've seen many nice sunsets here. It is paved, but of course to get closer views you're gonna want to walk around the hill so wear shoes with a good grip! Seen too many people almost slip lol. The parking areas can be a little sketchy. My fiance's rear window got smashed here a few years ago and there wasn't even anything in his car. So just use your best judgement I guess, try to park where there's alot of cars.
author: Aimee E.

description: One of San Francisco's secret spots for a great view of the city. Short easy trails that are dog friendly. There's an easy 20-30 min trail that leads you to the top with a cool swings. This view overlooks the city and will definitely provide you with many Instagram worthy shots that won't disappoint
author: Terry N.

description: I went here specifically for night photography of San Francisco. I parked in the very small lot (only fits 4 cars) that's located on Folsom St. From there it's a small walk uphill to get to the summit. Awesome views of San Francisco looking towards Mission and Downtown and then Twin Peaks area where you can see Sutro Tower off in the distance on the other side of the summit. Be sure to bring a sweater especially at night since it's windy and cold. I also brought a torch with me since I was going at night but it isn't necessary as I saw people walking in the dark.
author: Gerard Y.

description: Don't come here if you don't like dogs! Seriously! It's a dog park. People come to a dog park and then complain about dogs. This is one of only three off leash dog play areas in San Francisco. But you, you can run anywhere.
author: Anna K.

description:
Everyone has their own way to deal with a thing called "life". Some people shop. Some people gorge. Some people romance the bottle. Admittedly, I have done all these things for therapeutic purposes but they got me absolutely nowhere except broke(r) and fat(ter) with a bad hangover. 

Welcome to my new therapy: http://bit.ly/1zyBNWF and it's FREE! I was born and raised in San Francisco, and never even heard of Bernal Heights Hill. After searching for dog parks to bring Tater Tot, I stumbled across this place, and it has quickly become my favorite spot in the city to retreat to. Tater Tot's too!

The only thing that sucks is the drive to get there. The streets are tighter than a virgin's whoo haaa, and you have f*cktard drivers who will NOT stop to let you cross the street despite a florescent yellow sign that says, yield to pedestrians. San Francisco Recreation and Park, I hope you're reading this review. Please add a stop sign at the entrance of the park!

Parking is limited. There's 5 parking spots in front (1 handicap). I usually get lucky with parking, otherwise, I park on the dirt enclave to the right. 

Once you step through those gates, it's sensory bliss without the calories. The fresh air brushing against your face as you take in the 360 degree, sweepingly stunning views of San Francisco is unparalleled. I love that they have benches to plop my hiney on and get lost in the views so I can forget about the BS that life brings.

In the last 3 months, we've visited Bernal Heights Hill close to 30 times and I have encountered nothing but awesome people here. People smile and actually say, "hi". I've even exchanged numbers with a girl so we can meet up for walks. 

The trail from start to end takes about 15 minutes and another 15 minutes back but it takes us 45 minutes...one way because Tater Tot has a Napoleon complex. He feels the need to mark every corner of the 8+ bench posts, not to mention every corner of the 20+ posts in the surrounding area. Argh. 

Unlike some dog parks I've been to, furparents here are responsible and clean up after their furbaby drops a deuce or two. No poopy bags though so kindly make sure to bring your own. At the end of the trail, there's a water fountain for human and furbaby. I'm iffy about communal water bowls, so we always bring our own water. 

Most furbabies are off leash but I always keep Tater Tot on a leash for safety purposes. I was talking to another furparent and she told me some f*cktard set off fireworks on top of the hill one day, and several dogs took off running and got lost so please be careful!

Tater Tot was scared at first but after a few visits, he's now a champion butt sniffer at Bernal Heights Hill: http://bit.ly/1DHoxKe. There's always plenty of furbabies for him to see, smell, and play with. His favs are yorkie sisters: Mochi and Pepper. They always get him feeling some type of way, if you know what I mean. *wink wink*

If life has you feeling in the dumps, I highly recommend paying a visit to Bernal Heights Hill. It's the best therapeutic medicine you'll find in San Francisco...that's costs nothing at all! Free of debt, free of calories, free of hangovers, and most importantly, free of STDs. Because we all know people make the best decisions after 2 am right?
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Beautiful views of the city without swarms of tourists. This is a great little hike for walking your dog or just to get great views from the top. The hike has a slight incline and it's fairly easy. There's a large paved road that I believe most people take. There's also a little shortcut up some stairs and it's a much steeper climb. I was able to do it while wearing flats. It was super windy at the top, but it was worth it. We went on a clear day and caught 360 views of the city. We could see downtown, the bay bridge, and even the San Mateo bridge! There are also two tree swings at the top of the hill! Parking can be difficult, we parked in a tiny parking lot with only about 5 spots. Otherwise, you'd have to look for street parking.
author: Emily L.

description:
San Francisco, CA:  W-O-W.

Amazing.

Breathtaking.

Arrived by the #24 Cortland bus from Divisadero at McAllister. The Muni 311 helpline suggested I get off at Cortland /Bocana but a kindly gentleman residing in the neighborhood was about to get off at the following bus stop and suggested I follow him off. He pointed to Andover, said to take the stairs up to the top, and I will be at Bernal Heights Park. Sounded simple enough and away I went. Ten minutes later, after zig-zagging my way up alongside many pretty residential gardens, I literally arrived at Bernal Heights Park. The sign told me so.

The time was nearing 5:00pm, on a Sunday. There was a drinking fountain nearby and a sign with the name of the park inscribed on it. Wildflowers were blooming on the hill. Lots of poochies and their humans were coming and going. It looked like I still needed to climb up an incline for views so I went up to as close to the top as I legally could. 

There, I found jaw dropping views of San Francisco! Photos do not quite do the scenery justice. See yelp buddy Edwin R's review for a local's perspective of this "magical place." I was very moved and felt I wasn't ready to head home yet, despite the fact that I would  be leaving the next morning. Despite the many number of two and four legged creatures, the shade of the trees, the gentle breeze, the peacefulness, the beautiful sight of San Francisco below,  made me want to keep lingering. A place of rejuvenation in the middle of a great city.

But, evening called, and I still had to get down to Mission Street to catch the Muni (bus). Almost a tear and no happy smiles as I slowly found my way down the north side of Bernal Hill.
author: Shal W.

description: Small park but pretty cool.. might be crowded, but nice views and off leash friendly for doggos
author: Mason L.

description: One of my favorite places to go to in the city.  Doesn't get too crowded or touristy.  It's really more locals here either getting a quick workout in or taking a brisk hike up the hill.  Lots of dogs here too which is a plus.  The reason why this place is so popular though is because of the great view of the city - if its a clear day, you can see all the way out to the Golden Gate Bridge from one end to East Bay on the other.
author: David C.

description: This place is the perfect place to come on a sunny day for a family stroll! We brought our pup and she was able to go off leash. She was so giddy running around taking in the views of the city. A plus was the water fountain along the way so you can have the fur baby hydrate. We had our son in a stroller. The path is paved and low trafficked so it was a nice leisurely pace for baby. The path goes around a hill so you can take in gorgeous views of the city. I love that there are some benches along the way so you can really just hang out. Parking is cake in these parts. Go get some Mitchell's ice cream afterwards which is just a few minutes away!
author: Michelle T.

description:
One of SF's many great parks.  It's a neighborhood gem. The view is as good as Twin Peaks with almost no tourists (fingers crossed it stays that way) and way more dogs. Lots of paved road and dirt trails packed into a really small park. There's a swing at the top that seems to be more for instagram-ing than actual swinging. 

Best part is the Bernal coyote. The only thing that would make it better is a friend for the coyote. 

Overall, I'm always happy when I'm at Bernal Hill. Lucky to have it so close to home.
author: Marloes S.

description:
Okay I need to give this hike a try during the day time because the one time that my friend and I went was pitch black at midnight and it was terrifying and I thought I might die. That being said, it does offer absolutely breathtaking views of SF from the South. Twin Peaks is great and all but that's so cliche and hackneyed. Why not go for a real night adventure by driving up to the base of this peak and then taking the 5 minute ascent up? Be careful though since there are a lot of loose rocks and also one of those life-size stone mazes up here. The view of FiDi and Mission/SOMA area are wonderful--when you look at SF like this at night you begin to realize how grid-like the place actually is despite Market just cutting down the diagonal. It's crazy how when you're standing at the top of the mountain you can actually hear almost everything that's going on in SOMA... 

tldr; awesome place to go for a light hike to get some beautiful views of SF from a different perspective
author: Jasmine X.

description:
Good to check out once but unless you have a dog there's no need to return. 

Good view on a clear day but there's no grass or real trail-you basically just climb up a steep, rocky hill.
author: Rachel C.

description: dope park. doper views. any time of day, but my fav. is the golden hour. little hike up to the top, or you can enjoy the views from the street if you're... chillin' in the car. nice spot at night.
author: B S.

description:
This was the perfect followup, to exploring the Mission neighborhood. So many great views in every direction, plus it even gave me a chance to see towards the area where Candlestick Park stood(demolition begun on that as I heard back in early 2015, and my visit was spring 2014). You can see miles around, north to downtown, and also east towards the Port of Oakland and across the bay. Also a little artwork and graffiti, when you get to the top and are finished admiring the views all around.

Can't remember how my brother heard about this place, but however he found it, it's just as well he picked it over Twin Peaks. Didn't get to Twin Peaks, but maybe I will on another SF trip? I bet this place would be amazing for sunrise pictures, as well! Sat on this review unfinished for too long, so I just wanted to finish it once and for all almost a year later.
author: Allan M.

description: Bernal Heights, my experience here was poopy. No no not really poopy, but I mean like....yeah, poopy! *Refer to photos! I ventured on up to Bernal Heights in search for the painted rock. Apparently this rock gets painted every so often (not sure if this is an official thing or if it's random people painting it) but from people walking by it seems like it's been painted a number of times. From christmas trees to other things, and now the swirly smiling poop emoji! Anyway, I was very confused when I tried to climb the rock because it was extremely slippery yet I've seem so many people with their photos on top of this dang thing. I fell off. Completely just slipped right off, rolled into dirt, with everyone watching. WELP what can I say. Fortunately a random stranger stacked some rocks and whatnot and helped me up (TY STRANGER). Anyway, definitely visit this cool spot and hopefully catch the different paintings they do! And climb at your own risk and be careful!
author: Maleah M.

description: Beautiful views here at this dog friendly park. Come in the daytime on a clear day and you will be sure to love your visit... that is unless you are afraid of dogs. There is a trail that goes to the top which is just enough of a workout for me - a non gym rat at the moment. Maybe not so well known is this park more of a regular crowd rather than the tourist crowd.
author: Stefan T.

description: This is park is a bit of a hike, so if you are not ready for the walk take breaks there are lots of benches on the way to the top. A lot of dogs are running around and super friendly. If you come right before sunset you can get some great photos. The swing is a little awkward to get onto though.
author: Barry C.

description: Really good view of SF! There's plenty of parking at the base of the hill and walking up is no problem at all. The park is super dog friendly and seems like a good place to bring friends and watch the sunset. There's also a cute rope swing at the top!
author: Jessica Z.

description: A great place for humans and pooches ALIKE! My goodness! My hamstrings and glutes are killing me  (deep breaths! Deep breaths!). The climb is steep and therefore an excellent workout! If you don't want to work out - TRUST ME - the view will make all of those stairs worth it!! So worth it and my babies (ahem canine babies) loveeee it yaaaahh!!
author: Sarah M.

description: If you want a nice view of the West Bay skyline but loathe the crowds at Twin Peaks, Bernal Heights Park is an uncrowded, easily accessible option. In fact, it's easy to drive up to, and the hike to the top is very short. It's also a good area for dogs to roam about, and all in all it's a nice, compact vantage point that doesn't require significant effort. A must-see for anyone in love with the Bay Area.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Not recommended. Most dissapointing. No fence. Very hilly. No grass. Ground is only sharp rough gravel rocks prone to slipping. No place it sit. 

Great view at the top though.
author: Gary B.

description: It's a nice hike up to the park, and there's plenty of places to stroll. Lots of dogs off leash. Kind of the ideal place to take someone from out of town, especially if you want to avoid the line at Twin Peaks and still get your Instagram on.
author: Christina S.

description:
CLIMB EVERY MOUNTAIN!

Yes - to get to the MICROWAVE tower - you "gotta" climb, and climb, and climb!  We've been here several times, and each time, our dogs beat us to the top all leash free.  There are plenty of side, rocky roads where you can escape the jogger traffic. Bring water bottles folks even though there is a water fountain for humans and dogs at the entrance, cause once you get up there, it's a good hike down. There are a few benches but it's all about the hike. If you enjoy a good sweat, a good workout, target them cardio going, enjoy nature and being around the outdoor elements, enjoy getting a FIRM ASS BUTTOCKS, this is the place.  :p

PROS
--excellent photography view choice
--lots of hills to explore
--great for joggers
--great for hikers
--excellent for "well behaved dogs" (off leash)
--water fountain (humans and dogs)

CONS
-- limited parking
--can get super busy during peak times (3-7PM weekdays)
--weekends pretty busy

PS - bring your own pooch bags! :p

Cheers! ~
author: Edwin R.

description:
Short hike, amazing view!
You can see all of SF in a 360 angle, yes 360! You can see the city, bay bridge, golden gate bridge, and all the housing! I would definitely recommend Bernal Heights Park for a view of the entire San Francisco area! 

THERE IS A SWING AT THE TOP. Good spot to take photos while chillin on the swing!
author: Andrew S.

description: a nice slight uphill walk to the cliff that has a beautiful view of the City. Not much parking near the park so keep that in mind.
author: Stacey M.

description: Great place to walk.  Great views of the city! If you play pokemongo there are plenty of pokestops in the area and a gym.  There are benches if you want to sit and enjoy the views and a lot of dogs running around with their family having fun!!
author: Tina R.

description:
Bernal Heights Hill, you take my breath away.  Literally and figuratively.

Literally because of the hike it takes to get to the peak of the hill.  An easy hike There are several ways to get to the top.  I often start on the corner of Precita Ave and Alabama St (Precita Park Cafe) and take Alabama all the way up to enter on the east side.  If you want to enter through the north side of the hill, start at Precita Ave and Folsom St (Hillside Supper Club) and take Folsom top the top.  I recently discovered entering through the west side of the hill via the Esmeralda St. stairs.  From each location it should take about 10 min to get to the bottom of the hill and another 10 min to get to the top.  There are benches on the way to the top if you wish to take a break and soak in the beauty of the city.    

Figuratively becuase the views from the top are absolutely amazing.  You get a 360 degree view of the city which includes most of the landmarks (Bay Bridge, downtown, Coit Tower, TransAmerica Building, Golden Gate Bridge, and Twin Peaks to name a few.  Along with all of the neighborhoods in between).  I must say this is my favorite hill in the entire city.  Not because I live in this neighborhood, but you get a great views of the city without the cold, wind, and crowds you would get from Twin Peaks.  This hill is also easier to get to than having to drive up the windy roads Twin Peaks.  There's plenty of street parking and a small parking lot on the north side of the hill.  I've hiked up the hill during sunrise, sunset, and throughout all of the seasons and each time has been wonderful.  There's also a lot of cute dogs running around which is a big bonus for me.  Near the north east side of the hill you could see a small labyrinth made out of rocks simiilar to the one at the Lands End trail.  The biggest reward is the swing at the top of the hill.  

Find me hiking up this hill at least once a week.  The view from here never gets old.
author: Janice C.

description:
Beautiful 360 views of the city!! It's not really a hike, but you do have to walk up dirt paths to get to the top. You could walk circular routes or repeat routes to make it a hike if you wanted to. Dogs are free to roam around which is nice.

Basically, beautiful city views definitely worth a trip up to sit, relax, and enjoy.

Tip: Bring a jacket as it can get windy.
author: Charlton Y.

description:
I never review landmarks, but this spot is mind-blowingly beautiful. This is the quintessential San Francisco spot to bring family and friends who are visiting. The view here beats Twin Peaks' by a landslide. Why isn't this place more well-known than Twin Peaks?! I guess it's unpopularity keeps the tourists away, which is fine by me. 

From afar, the summit looks a bit bleak and bland. Due to the drought, the grass hasn't been as green and healthy. However, up close, the hill is quite charming. It's in the perfect location to give you a 360 view of the entire city. You feel closer to the city up here. There isn't really a paved pathway to get up the hill (at least, I didn't see one), so you should wear good shoes when you visit. It's a great spot to take in the scenery, drink some wine and relax.

I have to admit, my initial reason for visiting this summit was for the instagram worthy swing on top of the hill. We had initially visited Billy Goat Hill and the swing there was cut off! I was ecstatic to see that the one here is still in tact. I think the ideal time to visit is during sunset or sunrise, since there isn't much protection from the sun up here. Overall, I freaking love this hill so you should visit!
author: Joyce S.

description:
I don't know how a place like this only has some 48 reviews right now. I almost don't wanna write a review so I can keep it my little secret BUT this kind of beauty needs to be shared! If I ever needed to be reminded of how beautiful SF is, I'll always come here, Twin Peaks, or Battery Spencer. 

This location is fairly easy to navigate to, with pretty easy parking. I can't speak on the other side because I always enter on the same side, but to my knowledge, the parking is just street (read: parallel) parking. I've come here early in the morning and also at night, and I've never had issues finding parking. 

There's a brief walk to get to the top from the parking area. It's really up to you whether or not to go all the way to the top, but after walking ~5 minutes you're more or less surrounded by a 360 view of SF already. There's a single bench if you wanna sit, but I've found crossing over the barrier and sitting on the rocks on the hill work just as well. On a more recent visit, I was surprised to see that there's a swing at the top now! Fair warning, the swing is kiiiiinda high so if you're on the smaller side (5'3" and below), you might have some trouble getting up on the swing. Not that I tried to get on, fell off, and bled..or anything....but seriously, be careful please lol. Also, not sure if it's seasonal but when I went there were a ton of mosquitoes, so to all my fellow sweet blood homies: PROTECT YA NECK...and arms, and legs too! Just be liberal with that bug spray and I think you'll be okay.  

Overall, it's a pretty solid place to take your dog, get your cardio on, catch the sunrise, or to just take in the beautiful view of SF when Karl the Fog isn't around. Or you know, to get a picture that'll get you a good amount of likes on your Instagram, haha.
author: Gabrielle S.

description:
I love hiking up here or going here for a walk. I personally think this is THE BEST view of SF. There's a lot of nearby hills/heights/peaks, but I think this one takes the cake. You get a very wide/panoramic view of the city and a great view of downtown and the bay too. With other peaks/hills, there's usually something in the way. Or sometimes, the hill itself is already too near the center of the city, so you miss out of views of the entire city. With Bernal Hill, you can see downtown really well and all the neighborhoods leading up to it (mission, soma, dog patch, etc). 

I don't know how many other ways I can say this, but it's just THE BEST VIEW.

Other things to note: This is a dog park, so many people come and bring ALL their dogs. So if you love corgis, goldens, pugs, or any other kind of dog, you'll love this place.

There's a water fountain near the south entrance of the park. If you're thirsty, or if you have a friend who happens to have her contact fall out of here eye and you need to wash it out so she isn't blind in one eye.

If you want to actually walk up to the top/summit, there are actual walking trails that aren't super steep that lead you up there. So you don't have to take the makeshift/super steep trails, unless you want to.

To get to the actual hill can sometimes be tricky, as the roads wind around. But google maps usually helps me. If you're walking, I'd just put it into google maps. If you're driving, I'd just park wherever you feel comfortable (since most spots are parallel parking on a steep incline) and there's no actual parking lot.

People are super friendly here and in my experience more than happy to take pictures of you/for you/of themselves.

Also, it can be windy up here near sunset, so wear extra layers!
author: Julie L.

description: This is not a dog park. There are leash laws that apply to ALL dogs. Respect the leash law.
author: Jack S.

description:
One of the least effort, most gain-type walking spots in San Francisco. For the price of a single steep (but paved) hill up Folsom Street, and a moderate fire trail walk up to the top, you're treated to a lovely 360-degree view of San Francisco and surrounds. There are other ways to get up to the base of the park (via Bernal Heights, for example, where about 3 other main roads converge), but Folsom is the most direct from the Mission.

On a clear day, you can see: Downtown SF, Bay Bridge, the East Bay, Candlestick Point, the planes flying into and out of SFO, parts of the South Bay, Sutro Tower/Twin Peaks, all the nearby local neighborhoods, and the Marin Headlands/Golden Gate bridge. 

On a foggy day it's pretty windy, and on a clear day it can also get windy. Layer like your San Franciscan self ought to for optimal satisfaction. 

Nighttime can feel a little creepy because it's nature in the dark, but it's perfect on any fireworks holidays (sans fog) or for some rudimentary stargazing (you'd have to get pretty far out of the city to avoid light pollution entirely), but it's dark enough in the immediate vicinity for basic constellation-identification. 

Bernal Hill also a very popular dog playground, so if you're nervous about 4-legged creatures (or excited!) it's something to be aware of.
author: Krista L.

description: Fantastic view of San Fran. You can either walk up the hill though its steep no barrier for a faster route to the top or walk along the road where there is barrier for a longer but easier climb to the top. Its a pretty easy walk just start at the big rock and follow the trail. At the top there is a swing a bit scary at first but fun. Great view and not too crowded since its mainly people walking their dogs.
author: Prima Z.

description: Great views in the day, evening or night. There are many access points up. You can follow the main path up or other smaller man made paths that have been created (shortcuts or secret spots). Parking is easy around the entire area.
author: Erica Y.

description:
Great views of San Francisco! First time here, you get a 360 panoramic view compared to Lands End and such. 

Will bring my friend and the dogs to enjoy this open space. Not too crowded either. I was able to find my neighborhood easily.
author: Jenna R.

description:
Awesome park in the city to let your pooch run loose while you take in the amazing view of SF.

It's a short hike  - you have to go around the hill a few times or back and forth to really give your dog a good workout.  Typically not that busy, can get incredibly windy.. 

Not a daily park (imo) but a good "let's venture out to bernal today" type of park to take in the view of grab brunch in bernal afterwards.
author: Melody T.

description:
Absolutely beautiful. 

My cousin's partner walked us all the way up to the hill (my cousin drove and met us there haha) from their house. It was an exhausting climb, but very rewarding once reaching the top. It was beautiful weather with cute dogs running around. The fog made the view hazy, but beautiful to look out nonetheless. The view is stunning from the top.

It seems less crowded than Twin Peaks, also.
author: Dani P.

description:
The hike up here wasn't too bad, considering I did it in a Maxi dress. lol.
Also, take into account that it was soooooooo windy!

A lot of people bring their dogs here for walks. 
We ran into a snake along the path, it wasn't a small snake either. It was a good size, just be careful!

Up at the top there are several benches & places to post up & soak in the view. 

I have yet to go here at night but I have seen pictures & the view with the city lights is AMAZING! It is definitely on my list of things to do.

I recommend this short hike for an amazing view of the city.
Not much effort for something that is truly breath-taking.
author: Camille C.

description: Beautiful, calm park. Open layout. Good views of the city. Nice place to walk around. Near Bernal street slides, as well. Not over ridden with crowds of tourists. Come here to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city.
author: Joanna L.

description:
San Francisco is my home and Bernal is my hood. Bernal Heights stands tall to show off a stunning view of the city from different angles. Picture perfect Downtown, Mission, Noe, Excelsior, Bayview and beyond. 

My Dad and I like to walk up to Bernal. It's great exercise and when you reach the top of the mountain, the view is the prize.  You can sit on the top of the hill and listen to the sounds of the city or watch the city lights, blue skies or cute little puppies on their walks. 

We took my sister and 4yr old nephew the other day. I was worried he wouldn't be able to keep up, but he did. When we got up there, we took in the view and pointed out where everything was at to him. He was so excited to be able to see his school. 

I think the best part about returning to the hill each time is bringing someone new to check out the view. That's why I wanted to share my review with all of you! Check it out.
author: Rebekah T.

description: Great view and good for dogs. But make sure when you park , don't leave anything valuables. There are low life thugs watching us. I got my car broke into while I'm proposing to my girlfriend on the Christmas Day. How could they ?
author: Wei W.

description:
Great place for thinking
(5 stars)

Sometimes you just need to marvel at something and THINK. Always high view points are the best. Take it in and let it out. In hale and exhale. Pay no mind to those random dog walkers!!! 

After coming here to think I leave with clarity. Ready to let go of 2013. Ready to move on to a new career. Ready to have the future unfold. Ready for that moment I waited for years to happen. I get all emo, weird, and nostalgic at view points... They bring the best out of people. Go here. Be you with the world. Try it one time, you'll thank me later. Trust!!

I'm ready to do this!!!! Aaahhh!!!
author: Jane A.

description: Super underrated hill that gives you a sweeping view of the city! Great for dog watching and a nice little calf workout to boot. It's also a nice place for runners to do hill repeats :)
author: Kate T.

description: I absolutely love green spaces. As humans, it's in our nature to be drawn to the beauty of nature. Bernal Park isn't as big as some urban parks I've been accustomed to in Los Angeles but it perfect for San Francisco. From the top you'll get a 360 degree of this world renowned city. The views are spectacular especially on a clear night. It's my go to place to seek serenity and clarity of my mind. The park is frequent by many locals but isn't crowded even during peak hours. Its a great place for a picnic for couples or just to clear your head and enjoy the beauty of this dense city. Parking isn't bad at all and there aren't any steep inclines so its a great place for beginners although its about the size of Will Smith's estate (big but not huge). Check it out and remember to avoid littering. I'm watching you!!! Oh yes, dogs are welcomed!!!!!
author: Jermaine J.

description:
It was fun walking up the hill.

It's a pretty short hike. The longest hike would be about 15minutes long from Ripley street to the top and less than 4 minutes from Anderson street.

If you're afraid of dogs this is not a place for you or I would suggest taking the shortest route to the top which is from Anderson street. 

You'll see a lot of gorgeous dogs here big and small.
author: irwin v.

description:
This place has one of the best views in the city. Come during golden hour, and you're guaranteed to get a picturesque view of the bay. 

The "hike" can be as challenging as you want it to be. You can choose to park your car ~5 minutes from the hilltop, or you can park all the way at the bottom. 

**BUT if you are deathly afraid of dogs (big or small), I would be careful.Most owners let their dogs run loose around the park and hill. From my experience, most of the dogs were very obedient and respectful, but perhaps not the best place for those who are scared of dogs :C
author: Samantha C.

description:
Go when it is not foggy!! I was in the area checking out Dynamo Donuts and had to burn some energy to get hungry for dinner (first world problems, I know). Found this place on yelp and decided to explore. Paved path to the top is easy, not bad at all. While walking up the paved path, you'll see dirt trails of people ditching the trail and climbing straight to the top. I tried this and wow. Def wore the wrong shoes and def glad I didn't slip on the rocks and break my two front teeth. 

View at the top could probably be a nice view of the whole city but it was foggy so I couldn't see much. There were lots of people there with dogs, babies in strollers, bikes, and picnics. I didn't see any official picnic areas; it was an actual picnic with a blanket on the ground. There is parking as well if you don't want to walk up the trail. Somewhere near the parking is a labyrinth rock thing. It's a small but still really cool. 

I'd go here again just to walk around, relax, and maybe picnic on a blanket.
author: Esther C.

description: Don't write many reviews, but wanted to warn whoever comes here to keep your valuables with you or at home if you park here. I live in the neighborhood and always see broken car windows in that 4-5 space parking on the North side of the mountain Entrance on Folsom. Easy access to criminals. If you put something in your trunk and someone sees it, they will break your window and pop it from the inside. Think like a criminal and you'll lessen your chances of becoming a victim. Besides that, one of the best 360 views of the city day or night with a swing near the top.
author: Matthew P.

description:
The view from this hill is fantastic and getting up here is a good workout whether you walk, run or bike. If you're in the Mission and the weather is nice (which it almost always is) you shoud definitely take the time to get up here and maybe bring some food for a picnic!
On the 4th of July the Mission puts on quite the fireworks display and Bernal Heights provides a perfect view.
author: Albin B.

description:
The view deserves 5 stars but the park smells like dog piss and most owners don't use leashes.

& Woe to the retarded person that called the police on ALEX NIETO, another innocent young unarmed man murdered by the police w/ my tax dollars. He was a practicing Buddhist, employed and native to the area.

He has a memorial in the Park where he was shot.
author: Christie D.

description: Shhhhhh.  This place is terrible!  There are wildflowers in spring and you can see 365 degree views which is totally annoying.  Its really terrible to watch the sunset from here and there is no reason to break a sweat hiking up here for sunrise either after sipping some amazing coffee at Precita Park Cafe beforehand.  No one needs this hill here because its just gonna make you do a little exercise to get to the top when you can stay in Dolores Park or some other place!
author: Zach T.

description: This is a great place to walk your dog, take a nice little hike and just to enjoy the beautiful San Francisco views from every side of the hill. A bit windy on some days but well worth the chill.
author: Jaime P.

description: One of the coolest little hidden gems to visit at night. Just got home from here, my first time! A bit of a party spot, but if you mind your own, you'll be fine . There's a super cool swing that's slightly risky but a total blast. Can be a little Creepy up there at night...
author: Ciara F.

description: HANDS DOWN. This offers  the best view ofSan  Francisco Bay Are. Full Aeriel if you hike up from the towers a bit. Most finest at night when the city lights are on. Dogs are welcomed. Men, we recommend you take your first date out here because it is a beautiful sight to see ahah
author: KerryKevin G.

description: Perfect place to sit down and have one of the best views of San Francisco. If you have dogs bring them as well, it is the best place to have them unleash and have fun since it is safe and there is a vast of green area to run around. Just be aware of bringing a wind breaker jacket, it can get a little chill up there.
author: H C.

description:
I grew up on this hill. My heart is here. I love it in the waning days of summer when there is lots of time to linger on the hill while the sun goes down and the lights of the Mission wink awake to draw you down into the foodie-driven happyness that makes this grisled old Mission District boy so very proud. 

I have brought many dogs and many friends. I come up here on my moto, as the parking spots are few. I love spending time up here thinking alone, then wandering down onto Cortland Avenue to bid my heart adieu.
author: Kevin F.

description:
Beautiful panoramic view offered of the City. I took my Siberian Husky up here off leash and he loved climbing up the trail. Lots of rocks & dirt for him to play with and of course the strong wind blowing through his fur made it even that much better.

Parking isn't too hard to find around the residential areas leading up to the hill. Seems like there are a few different trails that all lead up to the top of the hill. It really allows you to view all the different parts of San Francisco. From downtown to the Marina, and everywhere else. I need to come back here during night to catch all the city lights.
author: Edison T.

description:
This place was great!  Full of nice people, great view!  Of leash plus dog fountain. & An amazing pano view of the city.

The only thing is just be careful if you go off the paved path, as the dirt paths are very slim, and it seems you can easily slip off the side and get extremely injured or even die.

Other than that, everything else was great.
author: Eli G.

description:
Love this park. I was just trying to kill time before meeting my brother for lunch, when I stumbled upon this park. The incline/hill makes it a decent workout (but not vigorous) and the view is beautiful. There are also a few benches along the trail, so you can just relax, soak up the view, and collect your thoughts. 

This would be a cute date, guys! Just sayin'. Good photo opportunities along the way.
author: Jamie M.

description: Love this place. Born and raised in the neighborhood and whenever I visit, I feel grounded and at home. The views are especially breathtaking at night. Can get really crowded on holidays, especially the fourth of July, but that's a no brainer. Definitely worth a visit if you're in the city
author: Hira S.

description:
Love this one! We found out about this place recently after living in the neighborhood for few years.
You cab see the whole view of the city:) Definitely taking my family and friends when they visit next time.
author: Maitai N.

description: Hidden gem of San Francisco. Great place to go for a hike and appreciate the view SF has to offer. A must-see!
author: Hua T.

description: I was first introduced to Bernal Heights Park a few years ago by a friend.  My friend lives down the street from this top of the hill park.  It's a short hike up there and we usually bring the dogs with us.  It's a popular park where dogs can go off leash.  The views are pretty amazing once you get up to the top.  On a non foggy day, you can see the San Francisco Bay, the Golden Gate Bridge, downtown, San Bruno Mountain, and the hills of the East Bay.  It's a great neighborhood park but also could be a tourist attraction for those who like to stray from the beaten path.  It does get quite windy up there though, so don't forget your jacket!
author: Liv A.

description:
No place to sit, and the lug of a hill, on the whole, is a bit brown and boring. The actual perimeter trail up and around is also a bit lacking... 

However, for dogs.. it's paradise... for those who like to train bleachers, go up and down on the west side through the stairs that dump down near Mission.

Boring brown loaf of a park. Once up there, though, nab one of the few benches, park thy glutes down, and behold the 360 views, though.. Then take yourself to Blue Plate and enjoy!
author: Jana C.

description: Dog lovers paradise with killer view of San Francisco!  I'm there every morning with my two doggies.  Lots of other friendly fur babies.  Bring good hiking or running shoes for gorgeous trails on hillside.  Bernal heights hill is absolutely a diamond in the rough
author: Shelly T.

description: What a great view. It's an amazing place to take SF newbies!
author: Chase L.

description:
There is something about that hill. I go up there and suddenly I feel energized! There is something going on up there... some kind of energy field! Best to go an hour before sunset and stay until the sun goes down completely.
And bring a good camera for time lapse. Its amazing to capture the shifting clouds and the transition from day to night!
author: Raymond C.

description:
My friend brought me to this park during my visit and I'd definitely recommend it. The view of the city is truly spectacular! We went when it was dark and I was mesmerized by the glistening building, street, and bridge lights.

Getting to the view was fun, if not a bit treacherous. It seemed as if we took a route through somebody's side yard (my friend insisted that it was part of the park). The path up the hill was steep and laden with loose stones that slipped beneath our feet. It was especially dangerous since nothing in the park was lit and our footing was uncertain.

I was surprised that at the top of the hill was a fenced off area. My friend explained that it was a cell phone tower. How unfortunate that we couldn't summit because of the fence, but could navigate the circumference of the tower.

I noticed a few couples sitting on the incline of the hill along the path. Although I fancy the notion, I also am skeptical considering the vast amount of loose stones. I would worry that at any moment my romantic picnic could transform into a deathly slide. There was very little visible grass on the hill making it seem that the primary attraction is the terrific view of San Francisco.
author: Yvonne B.

description: The view from Bernal Heights is incredible. There are not many places east of Twin Peaks where you can see as far north as the Golden Gate bridge and as far south as San Bruno mountain. Plus, the surrounding neighborhood is adorable. Take a picnic, enjoy the view, and try not to get stuck on a steep slope!
author: Sophia A.

description:
Beautiful views of the Bay and a nice little walk too. If you have a doggie that doesn't roam for miles by himself then you can get in some nice off leash action. 

Unfortunately I have a doggie that *does* likes to roam for miles by himself, so I have to stick to bigger parks like Funston or fenced in places like Douglass. So I didn't come up here with Captain D, but I did come up here with brother Mike and fortunately he is far better trained.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
I have intended to go to this park for a while now.  Today I took a rather circuitous route to get here.  Up one street, down another, down this dead end street and back the other way.  I just wanted to get out for a while and decided to walk up to this hill.

There are lots of paths, but many are not paved and are loose rock so watch your step.  There is a paved path for service vehicles, but I don't think you have to worry much about them going up here. 

Dogs run free off leash.  I think the views are better here than at Twin Peaks, and there's less crowds to deal with.  You won't find much parking here, so hike up these hills and check out the sights.

Somebody made a labyrinth that is like the one at Grace Cathedral, but about half the size out of all the stones up here.  You'll find it near one of the entrances on Anderson Street.  Bring good walking shoes, clear your mind, and enjoy one of the higher points in San Francisco.
author: Michael M.

description:
This is a hidden gem hike near the end of the mission.  Its very short (15-20 minutes walking from Mission St.) and its easily done by anyone.  While steep and step-filled, it's totally worth the magnificent view of SF, downtown, and the bay bridge.  If it's a sunny day, it's a perfect hike for a nice glimpse of the city while not having to go too far.

Must do for the SF bucklist!
author: Robert T.

description:
everybodys got their favorite spots here in the city be it an sf moment, timing, good company, proximity or scenery which there's plenty of on this 7x7

can't name a favorite as there's so many, however this one is certainly climbing the charts and can be mentioned w/the best of 'em.

we really are lucky to live in such a beautiful city
author: Clark G.

description: Great views of the city:) Very peaceful, lots of dogs too but not crowded (in the morning at least).
author: Liza S.

description:
LOVE. LOVE. LOVE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

AMAZING VIEW OF THE CITY!! I think I like it even better than Twin Peaks because

1. Not a lot of tourists! Mainly people that live in the area plus their dogs! :)
2. More greenery!! Flowers!! 
3. People have to park their cars at the bottom of the hill, as opposed to having a parking lot RIGHT THERE at Twin Peaks, which kind of ruins the whole atmosphere.
4. Bernal Heights Hill is better suited for picnicking!

You can sit in the grass, sit on rocks that jut out...sit ANYWHERE! Just be wary of dog poo.
author: Kei H.

description:
A good urban hike.  You see fantastic views when you reach the top of the hill.  The trail is a gradual incline and decline for all levels of hikers, walkers, and joggers.  Dog friendly park.

There are many places to park around the hill.  I suggest taking the hike to another level for those living outside San Francisco.  We took BART from the Daly City BART station to the 24th & Mission station because it was easier to park at the station; moreover, parking is free on weekends.  We walked east on 24th street and turned right on Folsom Street.  The most difficult part of the urban hike is the steep hill on Folsom.  Go slow and you make it to Bernal Heights Boulevard.  Find the Bernal Heights Park trail and enjoy the easy and gradual incline to the top.

I didn't see any bathrooms.  I saw a few water fountains for people and dogs.  There were plenty of benches.  Bring a camera to take pictures of the many San Francisco viewpoints including Downtown, Candlestick Park, and Sutro Tower.
author: Raymond M.

description:
Competes with Tank Hill (http://www.yelp.com/biz/YaOHbbseQ-5J-VLBh6iPQw), Corona Heights (http://www.yelp.com/biz/tGCFC0PTjLbU5m7Euw2NJg), and Twin Peaks (http://www.yelp.com/biz/WV2fVK6OJfzn2BkRGpbP7A) as the best view of the city. As you walk around the fenced structure at the top, hill offers 360 degrees view (not from one spot) from Candle Stick to downtown to Noe Valley (see pic).  You cannot drive up to the view point like Twin Peaks, but you don't need to deal with tourists here.  People bring dogs here, which I don't really understand, because the hill is made of small rocks, so I don't think it's pleasant for the hairy ones.  

If you just want to hangout for a while, I felt that Tank Hill or Corona Heights provided a more calming feel.
author: トモ T.

description:
Such a breathtaking view up at the top!

If only I knew to start at the end of the hill...my bad....
Great for people who likes taking scenic pictures!
author: Anna L.

description: I've noticed this hilltop park passing by from 101 and have wanted to check it out for a while. I finally got around to stopping here on my way home from work one day and really glad I did! Awesome views of downtown as well as most of the rest of the city. I got here right around 5 PM, which was perfect timing to watch the fog roll in from the west. Great place to get some amazing pictures! Since I live nearby I will definitely be back. There was a lot of people out walking their dogs. So, if you've got one, bring them here, they seem to love it as well!
author: Adam K.

description: Favorite place to go for a run, fly a kite or simply walk. The view is amazing. On a foggy or sunny day, the view & environment are always fantastic. If you're not from the city, this place should definitely be on your bucket list!
author: Maritza S.

description: Gorgeous views- beautiful park to explore with your dog. There are always friendly owners and dogs checking out the trails- just be aware that pups run around off leash. Absolutely love this place and visit often.
author: Steph P.

description:
I actually found this park by accident. I hopped on the 67 MUNI from the 24th and Mission BART and passed by the park. 

It has amazing views of the city and I think would be a cool place to have a romantic picnic. There are a lot of people around with dogs, but that could be both a plus and minus. 

VIEWS VIEWS VIEWS.

To get a sense of the views, see: 

http://flickr.com/photos/calmenda/sets/72157603708450407/
This park doesn't have much other than the views, but that alone gets it four stars.
author: Carlos A.

description:
I had planned a walk from Glen Park Bart to Bernal Heights just to browse some shops and walk the "hill." I thought you'd just walk up and be like "oh, very nice" and come right back down. This was so much more than I expected. It was a pretty windy day and foggy as you looked towards the west, but pretty amazing nonetheless. 360 degree views of SF and lots of little narrow trails in addition to the paved path.
It was pretty magnificent up there and even the walk back down to Cortland was fun as you can wind your way through the neighborhood streets and little hidden staircases here and there. A definite off-the-beaten path must!
author: Jennifer N.

description: A great view of the city if you wait until the morning fog clears. There are dozens of dogs running around, in addition to runners and walkers. The walk up is fairly easy and there are benches and a cute tree swing at the top!
author: Abby S.

description:
We love this dog park and so does little Mochi!! We love the fact that it isn't like any other dog park, where your dog is kept in a fenced off area...what fun is that?! 

Dogs are free to run off leash here, and lots of running they do! The paved pathway is closed off to vehicles, so you don't need to worry about that. There's always lots of dogs here; small, medium and large and all very friendly. 

Not to mention, there are also dirt paths up the hill with such amazing views of the city and no need to deal with the crowds at Twin Peaks! This has got to be the area's best kept secret, I swear. But don't worry, for those not wearing the proper shoes or not up for a small hike up the hill, the paved paths also give great views of the city, along with appropriately placed benches to take it all in.
author: Ly T.

description: My friend and I came up here on a foggy evening. While I wish that it had been a little clearer, getting to see the city from here was still such a beautiful experience. I saw a lot of dogs, too, which was an added bonus. :)
author: Kelly R.

description:
I recently adopted a poodle and am in need of trails long enough to tire my little one out.  Fortunately, I learned about this park via Yelp (thanks Yelp community!) and what everyone says is true.

The views at this place are spectacular!!  There is ample parking all around the base of the hill.  This place is VERY dog friendly.  I feel like all I saw were people walking their dogs.  There are only 2 or 3 trash cans (all at the base of the hill), so be prepared to carry your trash out.  Also, it is SUPER windy.  Not sure if it's like that all the time or only in Aprils around 5PM... in either case, bring something wind proof for you and your pup.  And also bring gloves!!  Despite wearing a hooded sweatershirt, denim jacket, and long sleeve shirt, I was still wishing I had on gloves and a down jacket/Northface. 

I too was surprised at how much lose rocks there were on the trails.  Wear good shoes and socks -- lest gravel creep into your shoes or you twist your ankle!!  Especially when you take into account the wind!!  It almost knocked us over.  

Overall, I had a great time.  My dog and I spent over an hour walking around and chatting with other dogs and their owners.  And when we got home, my dog was knocked out for the rest of the evening.  I highly recommend this and for sure will return!
author: Ohns O.

description: gorgeous view. can see a beautiful panoramic view of SF. but please, for the love of everything that's good in the world, PLEASE BRING ALLERGY MEDICINE AND TAKE IT BEFOREHAND. trust me, you'll thank me later.
author: Denise R.

description:
I've lived in the Bay for two years, but had never heard of this place until I came here a couple weeks ago. My friend and I ended up going on a rather foggy and chilly day, but it was a stunning view of the city and a rather secluded spot. 

Make sure to bring a jacket and wear good hiking shoes, because the climb up to the peak is a bit steep and rocky. And then prepare to sit back and enjoy a wonderful view of the best city on the planet. :)
author: Crystal J.

description: The only downside of this park is that there is no real upkeep on it. However, there are some amazing views of the city that can be had from here. There are always at least a few people walking their dogs here, this allows your dog to be social with them :)
author: Robert H.

description: The views here rival Twin Peaks. Definitely make it a point to visit and bring your pup too!
author: Sofia M.

description: Another awesome view of the city. We walked up at night to see the city lights and they did not disappoint.
author: Andrew S.

description: Wow, this park was a wonderful surprise. What a view!I Love the view of the pink mural on the  modern home at the base of the park as well
author: V V.

description: Decided to take my date for a non drinking/eating experience and make him climb/chill out on this hill at the crack of dawn - to which he kindly obliged :) Awesome way to have the guy "show me" SF via panoramic view and allowed us to feel more casual and connect sober. Views are spectacular
author: Gargi M.

description:
If heaven does exist, I can only hope it'll be like Bernal Heights Hill, where friendly dogs roam freely and humans, both young and old, are happy and content.

I am so glad to find out about this place on Yelp. We took our Mokka here for a walk on a Sunday afternoon, with the warm sun and cool breeze, children laughing in the background, some families flying kites amidst amazing views of San Francisco. 

It was atop Bernal Heights Hill that I had a moment of clarity and content. My heaven does exist... it was Bernal Heights Hill all along.
author: Nancie T.

description:
A very nice place to see a 360 degree view of the area. 

Parking is plentiful and there is a dog park at the base.

Gorgeous Views!!!!

If you like photography... this is definitely a spot to shoot.
author: Roger A.

description: Best place to see lots of interesting dogs and people. Also a great view of the city.
author: Erin C.

description:
My dog insists that I take him to this park at least once a week.  If you look at my profile pictures, you'll see many a photo of him taken up there.  The views are spectacular and the walk is vigorous, but not all that difficult.  

If you ever get a chance to visit Bernal Heights Park you'll feel like you're on top of the world.
author: Landy G.

description: This is a beautiful park with views of the entire city. People bring their dogs to the park. There are lots of trails and benches to sit on. This is a great place to have a picnic. There are few trash cans though, so be prepared to carry your trash out with you.
author: Pillowsblanket S.

description:
What in the....?? This place exists?! 

I nearly smacked myself in the forehead for living in SF for almost 5 years without even knowing this place existed.  Shame on me!  I came here on an "urban hike" with a girlfriend who lived nearby and I'm so happy she introduced me to this place.  Amazing views of the city, a great uphill climb to work your booty, and adorable dogs and friendly people all over the place. 

Thankfully we came on a gorgeous weekend morning and the views were incredible.  I had never seen SF from this angle before and soaked in every minute of it.  

Definitely would recommend this place to anyone to hang out, catch some views, and get a pretty good workout while you're at it.  Close to Cortland Ave. where all of Bernal's tasty eats are concentrated so make a date out of it. You won't be disappointed!
author: Naoko M.

description:
Having this just a few blocks from home makes it ideal for my pups and socialization with others, both canine and human. Amazing views of downtown and surrounding bay. With the sun shining on the hill of my new hood, it feels like a vacation.
